Award.AwardTitle: New vistas: The intersection of endangered languages and language change at the 23rd International Conference on Historical Linguistics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists estimate that at least half of the 7,000 languages worldwide will cease to be spoken by the end of the current century. Statistics published in 2016 by Glottolog, an online reference guide to the languages of the world, notes that this represents 242 distinct language families and 188 families with only one member ("isolates"). Scientific knowledge of how languages are related to one another and how languages change (known as "historical linguistics") has focused primarily on one language family, the Indo-European family, which includes English, Spanish, among others. How do studies of other language families, particularly those that are endangered, inform scholarly research about the way languages change? And how does the field of historical linguistics advance scientific understanding of endangered languages? This workshop will address these two questions as part of an international conference on historical linguistics. Broader impacts include funding to support the participation of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Broader impacts also include dissemination through the inclusion of online materials which will widen access, and submission of select conference papers to be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

The University of Texas at San Antonio will host the 23rd International Conference on Historical Linguistics (ICHL 23). Bridget Drinka, along with collaborator Patience Epps, of the University of Texas at Austin, will organize a conference program that includes a special focus on endangered languages and historical linguistics. ICHL 23 will include plenary speakers and discussants, drawing from endangered language researchers who comprehensively represent different geographic regions, language families, and typological diversity. The speakers will bring a breadth of methodological and theoretical expertise relating to the study of language change, spanning traditional reconstruction, approaches to language contact, phylogenetic methods, and other perspectives. Additional presentations at the conference will touch on the intersection of endangered language study and historical linguistics. Participating researchers will include junior scholars whose participation will be funded by this award. ICHL 23 will focus attention on the exciting new directions in which these fields are moving. A relatively recent subfield of linguistics, language documentation has been gaining ground in recent years. As language documentation continues to develop its depth of engagement with and contribution to other subfields, the value of this area amongst scholars and members of the general public will grow. Likewise, the subfield of historical linguistics has much to gain from the exciting new directions offered by work in underexplored language families and regions of the world. These new vistas of exploration promise to deliver fresh perspectives and innovative approaches to the discipline of historical linguistics, which will benefit significantly from this reinvigoration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project highlights the important synergy between the documentation of endangered and lesser-studied languages and the study of historical linguistics, via a panel held at the 23rd meeting of the International Conference on Historical Linguistics, held in San Antonio, Texas in August 2017. The panel brought together students, post-doctoral scholars, and established researchers to draw attention to this topic and to learn from each other’s work. Video recordings of the talks are available online at https://liberalarts.utexas.edu/lrc/extras/ichl/index.php#endangeredlanguagehistoricallinguistics. See also the ICHL conference website at http://ichl23.utsa.edu/, and the webpage for the panel at http://ichl23.utsa.edu/panel-endangered-languages-and-historical-linguistics/. An edited volume is also in progress that showcases much of the work presented. These products ensure that the insights resulting from the panel are freely available to a broad international audience.

The panel on Endangered Languages and Historical Linguistics, together with the resulting volume in progress, has provided a significant opportunity for experts and graduate students from around the world to gather in one location to demonstrate the contributions that the study of endangered and less-studied languages can make to historical analysis, and, in particular, to allow for an interrogation of the assumptions of many traditional historical linguists regarding models of change that are constructed primarily with reference to standard and well-attested languages.  As a range of studies have demonstrated, under-studied languages – many of which are highly endangered – frequently yield novel and important insights concerning pathways of grammaticalization, forms and dynamics of contact-driven change, and diachronic relationships among lexical and grammatical categories. At the same time, the panel and volume highlight the relevance of an attention to diachrony in endangered language research – whereas earlier approaches to linguistic description placed a heavy emphasis on synchrony, more contemporary approaches have demonstrated that an awareness of processes of language change lead to more satisfying explanations for synchronic variation, and thus richer documentation and description. This in turn deepens our understanding of human cognition, interaction, and history.

As a symposium of world-renowned experts on endangered languages embedded in the most important international conference on historical linguistics in the world, this panel and the resulting volume are expected to have a significant impact on the trajectory of both endangered language research and historical linguistics in the future.  The day-long panel attracted a large audience of historical linguists; the four plenary speakers serving as discussants for the panel also brought prominence to the issues under consideration, both by their analysis and synthesis in reaction to the panel, and in their own plenary talks focused on endangered and less-studied languages. The panel and volume have drawn and continue to draw attention to the new insights that the investigation of these under-studied language families and regions of the world contribute to our understanding of language change; this new perspective yields fresh insights and approaches to the discipline of historical linguistics, which is already beginning to benefit significantly from this reinvigoration. Likewise, the panel and volume highlight the theoretical importance of documentary and descriptive work on endangered languages. This focus contributes to the valorization of endangered language documentation within the wider field of linguistics, and likewise transfers to communities of speakers, heritage communities, and other entities. Finally, the panel and volume contribute to the training and professional development of the students and post-doctoral participants, who were able to present their work to a wide audience and to explore ways that their own research can benefit from the insights and discoveries of the other participants.
